entry.title: Corus KLCC: Celebrate the Christmas & New Year's festive season with buffet feasts
entry.content:
Celebrate Christmas and New Year in style with buffet feasts that feature fabulous holiday dishes at Corus KLCC!

Seasonal specials seize the spotlight for the Christmas Eve Buffet Dinner, including roast lamb and chicken, carved for your pleasure, prepared with flavourful blends of herbs and spices.

From sparklingly fresh seafood to delightfully tempting desserts, enjoy Corus KLCC's festive cheer and charm with your family, friends and colleagues.

Early reservations are highly recommended -  contact Corus KLCC at +6012-287-5820 or +6012-282-0786 for enquiries and bookings now.

Christmas Eve Buffet Dinner
Date: 24 December 2024
Time: 6:30pm–10pm
Price: RM148++ per adult, RM78++ per child
Special Offer: Enjoy Early Bird discount at 20%* until 16 December 2024.

Christmas Buffet Hi-Tea
Date: 25 December 2024
Time: 12:30pm–4pm
Price: RM78++ per adult, RM48++ per child

New Year’s Eve Buffet Dinner
Date: 31 December 2024
Time: 6:30pm–midnight
Price: RM168++ per adult, RM88++ per child
Special Offer: Enjoy Early Bird discount at 20%* until 16 December 2024.

New Year Buffet Hi-Tea
Date: 1 January 2025
Time: 12:30pm–4pm
Price: RM78++ per adult, RM48++ per child

The New Year’s Eve Buffet Dinner and New Year’s Buffet Hi-tea will showcase global cuisines with premium dishes to satisfy every palate. Count down to midnight with lively music, giveaway party packs, a Best Dress Competition, and a toast to new beginnings.

Special Year-End Festive Offer at RM588++ per night 
Stay in Deluxe room inclusive of Christmas Eve or New Year's Eve Buffet Dinner and Buffet 
Breakfast for Two. Bookable via corusklcc.com until 31 December 2024, for stay date on 24 December and 31 December 2024.

*With terms and conditions. Price is subject to 10% service charge and prevailing government tax.

Watch our video here!





Sink your teeth into Christmas succulence: The Roasted Lamb Leg with Roasted Potatoes and French Beans will have everyone returning for second and third helpings, thanks to terrifically tender meat with a rich, deep taste.

Fans of Roast Chicken, bookmark Corus KLCC for your year-end celebrations: The chefs have harnessed their personal recipe for this whole chicken, perfectly cooked so that each bite is smooth and full-bodied for maximum meaty satisfaction!
  


Other exclusive highlights for Christmas Eve include Pan Fried Duck Breast with Onion Sauce, Poached Salmon Fillet with Garlic Butter Cream Sauce, Baked Lamb Shepherd’s Pie, Braised German Beef Roulade with Stuffed Gherkins and Egg, and more, representing many of Europe's traditional festive recipes.


There's something for everyone across Corus KLCC's spread, from captivatingly juicy crustaceans, mouthwatering mussels and silky smoked salmon to classic cold cuts and hot, heartwarming fare.





Save space for a spectacular sweet finish, including beloved Yuletide favourites like the Yule Log and Summer Bread Butter Pudding with Orange Vanilla Sauce, all beckoning beautifully beneath Corus KLCC's Christmas trees!




Corus Hotel Kuala Lumpur, Jalan Ampang, 50450 Kuala Lumpur.
Tel: +6012-282-0786 or +6012-287-5820

entry.title: The Humboldt Co, Bukit Damansara
entry.content:
The Humboldt Co is Bukit Damansara's tantalising new thematic bar with South American inspirations. 

Its name is inspired by the ocean current that flows from Chile, reflected in walls that nod to Humboldt penguins and a striking back bar that simultaneously evokes the geometric contours of Antarctic icebergs and the sandy orange hues of Peru's coastal deserts.

Chilcano is one of our favourite cocktails this year, sharpening the floral Chilean El Gobernador Pisco with triple ginger, apple cider vinegar, mustard, citrus and carbonation.

For a more mellow mood, Anisada is a nectarous comforter of Tanqueray No. 10 Gin with Aperol, fig, eucalyptus and honey. Low-proof and zero-proof drinks are also available.

Food should be available soon this month, with potential highlights like rabbit prepared in the style of South American guinea pigs.

entry.title: Satellite Restaurant & Bar, Imperial Lexis Kuala Lumpur
entry.content:
From golden hour to twilight and beyond, Satellite Restaurant & Bar on the 53rd floor of Imperial Lexis Kuala Lumpur is KL's vantage point for an evening of excitement, with wide-open views of the city's sprawling skyline.

Watch the sun set over iconic skyscrapers like the Petronas Twin Towers, KL Tower and others, then settle in for a night of fun food and delightful drinks at this vibrant new venue. Top tip: It's sure to be a popular spot to ring in 2025 with a spectacular fireworks display!

This sheltered alfresco setting promises an unparalleled experience for cool evenings, with an unobstructed bird's-eye panorama from one of the city's highest bars.


If you're tired of cramped, claustrophobic bars, Satellite Restaurant & Bar is a refreshing alternative - the sense of space is liberating, with cosy corners to explore, from the main bar section with a DJ's booth to a discreetly hidden lounge with a prime peek at peaking towers.

Many patrons prefer to flow in just before sunset – a captivating time to snap the most dramatic images of KL's cityscape – and stay throughout the evening to capture another facet of the KL skyline, as the bright lights enliven the night.


The enchantment extends to midnight every day - if you're seeking an impressive perch for a romantic date, Satellite Restaurant & Bar will ensure truly special memories.

Catch all the action-packed buzz as Satellite Restaurant & Bar's bartenders mix a medley of mouthwatering cocktails and mocktails with flair and finesse, creating visual pleasures that thrill the taste buds as well.


The Magellanic Cloud is made for sharing (RM188; easily for four persons.) It’s part of The Multiverse series of cocktails at Satellite Restaurant & Bar - a whimsical blend of whisky with absinthe, for a potent punch of full-bodied smoothness, well-balanced with notes of spice and herbs, playful with popcorn and beer reduction, finished with fluffy 'cloud' cotton candy.


Rocketing into our list of favourite cocktails, The Galaxy series unlocks a new universe of tastes and textures for cocktail connoisseurs - ladies in red might favour the Redshift to Red Dress (RM78; a seductive scarlet sensation of gin with Galliano liqueur and sparkling wine, blushing beautifully with strawberries, watermelon, thyme, vanilla and lime) and Whirlpool In My Head (RM58; whiskey with Starlino Arancione, red dragonfruit, elderflower and lemon).


Mocktails are equally enticing, with compelling concoctions like the Gamora Sour (RM32; apple and vanilla soda with peach and lemon) and Love & Thunder (RM32; passionfruit and pineapple with ginger, mint and lime), scintillating with ripe fruity sweetness.



Satellite Restaurant & Bar elevates bar snacks into lip-smacking crowd-pleasers for a delicious dinner. 

Sink your teeth into the Mixed Grilled Satay (RM48), showcasing three skewers each of wagyu beef and chicken for a satisfyingly meaty chew, surprisingly smokey for fans of classic Malaysian flavours, complete with compressed rice, cucumber, onions and thick peanut sauce.



Wagyu Beef Tacos (RM78) bring together Tex-Mex crunch with creamy, carnivorous juiciness in crispy corn tortillas packed with shredded beef, cheese, tomatoes and tangy ranchero sauce.



Round out this wonderful wagyu encounter with Wagyu Beef Sliders (RM88). The lusciously layered brioche buns feature tender wagyu beef patties, pickles, and Comte cheese, brilliant for burger buffs.



Prefer poultry? Munch on the Furikake Chicken Popcorn (RM48), crackly with robust marination, delectable for dunking in tonkatsu mayo for bursts of rich umami flavour.



Linger on for the Lime Cheesecake (RM42), colourfully exuberant with nuances of lime and berry compote to buoy the sweet savouriness of the cheesecake.



Satellite Restaurant & Bar
53nd Floor, Imperial Lexis Kuala Lumpur, 15, Jalan Kia Peng, 50450 Kuala Lumpur.
Open Daily, 5pm-12am
For bookings & enquiries: 
+603-2177-1188 or +6010-784-0176 (WhatsApp)
eat@imperiallexiskl.com
Booking link: 
letsumai.com/widget/satellite-imperial-lexis

Website & Social Media Info:
imperiallexiskl.com/dining/satellite-restaurant-bar
instagram.com/imperiallexiskl
facebook.com/imperiallexiskl
tiktok.com/@lexishotelgroup
#MYLexis #ImperialLexisKL

entry.title: Wangsa Walk Mall: Stock your home & shop at Christmas bazaars throughout December
entry.content:
Cookies and collectibles, kitchenware and ceramics, clothes and custom art, fragrances and fun: Shop at Wangsa Walk Mall's Christmas bazaars this month with various vendors for all your year-end household and gifting needs.

Discover these bustling bazaars until 29 December 2024 at Wangsa Walk Mall's two main courts, including beside its main entrance, decked with decorations including festive trees and candy canes.

Also send a wish card to Santa here to stand a chance to win vouchers to Roller Light, Wangsa Walk Mall's neon-lit, nostalgia-infused indoor roller skating rink!





Awesome Snacks has a huge range of homemade snacks, spanning jars of marshmallows, pretzels and biscuits to boxed bundles of caramel cookies and icing sugar cookies.


Cookies by Luvliy will tempt traditional taste buds with pineapple tarts, chips, love letters, biscuits and classic cookies.


Ampang-based bakery Paamaa Dessert will satisfy the sweet tooth with Hokkaido butter cakes, Swiss rolls, marble cheesecakes, and doughnuts in sprinkled and sugar-glazed varieties.


At Court 1, check out purveyors like OsmanliOud, with a collection of Ottoman-inspired fragrances from Turkey, with Istanbul-inflected artistry.



JJ Perfume promises scent-sational perfumes with Swiss formulas, alongside an assortment of of hair care products from South Korea's Insight.


For the polished professional, head into 2025 with American brand Case Logic's laptop-friendly bags and cases that last.





Meow Studio, Luvliy Vintage and other purveyors offer necklaces, bracelets, rings, phone straps, trinkets and tiny figurines of popular animation characters. You'll also find jewellery made with 92.5% silver.


Seeking a new phone case this Christmas? Find Foneshark for cool, colourful varieties! 


Laser Art will print custom art on wooden ornaments and platters using any photo of your choice, ready in 20 minutes! The perfect personalised gift to celebrate the Yuletide season!



Heading to Wangsa Walk Mall's Court 2, the shopping selection includes Simply Home, with many bargains on bedding, towels, storage and kitchenware.



Mae Kitchenette is your stop for 100% ceramic products that are safe for microwaves and dishwashers, complying with halal product requirements.


Children's clothes come with bulk buying promotions, such as Buy 7 Free 1 deals for RM12 items and Buy 4 Free 1 for RM25 items.


Toys are also available at a Buy 1, Free 1 promotion for a wide range of ages, featuring bright trucks and building blocks, dinosaur models and action figures.



Santa’s Wish Card lets participants write a wish to Santa to potentially win a voucher to Roller Light! Include your name and contact details to redeem the voucher at the management office.

How to participate: 
1 - Follow and Like Wangsa Walk’s Facebook page at facebook.com/wangsawalkmall and Instagram at instagram.com/wangsawalkmallofficial
2 - Write in your most creative wishes to Santa on the card provided
3 - 'Mail' it in the mailbox provided
4 - Six winners will be announced weekly on Wangsa Walk’s social media platforms every Saturday (7, 14, 21 and 25 December 2024)



Wangsa Walk Mall
Wangsa Avenue, Jalan Wangsa Perdana 1, Bandar Wangsa Maju, 53300 Kuala Lumpur.

entry.title: Await Cafe relaunches following remarkable refurbishment in Taman Desa
entry.content:
The wait is over: Await Cafe has relaunched following a remarkable refurbishment, reflecting two months of meticulous carpentry with artistry in wood, stained glass panels and stark light bulbs.

Delightful details abound in this Taman Desa stalwart, marking its twelfth-year milestone with this transformation, inspired by Taipei coffeehouse charm to complement mainly Taiwanese-roasted beans for light-bodied, clean-tasting hand brews, smooth and soothing.

It’s thoughtfully mindful - everything from the height of the functionally practical bar to the colour choice for the freshly painted walls to the textures of the tableware provides a calm, comfortable encounter with slow-living philosophies. Even the elevated floor evokes a canvas, representing splashes of spilled coffee.

Await Cafe is now serving by reservations only for a patient, personal experience. In mid-December, it’ll reopen for walk-ins, likely with pastries, bagels and sourdough bakes.

entry.title: Jom Makan Minum Lah Cafe, Bandar Sri Damansara
entry.content: Bandar Sri Damansara's friendly new Jom Makan Minum Lah Cafe invites customers to customise their local favourites - pile your fried rice with add-on choices such as char siew (sourced  straight from SS2's TNR by Sean & Angie), prawns, pork lard and fried egg; heap your kueh teow th'ng with bouncy fish balls and firm fuchuk.

entry.title: Inoha, Ara Damansara
entry.content:
Bursting with colourful culinary creativity, Inoha is now officially open in Ara Damansara, serving flavourful specialities with inventive inspirations.

The Mori Mizu Chazuke infuses twists of tempeh and chai poh into the Japanese classic, a soulful and steamy pour-over of tea on rice, coated with chuka wakame, edamame, cherry tomatoes, cucumber, corn, beans, spring onions and shallots, a wholesome heart-warmer for meat-free Mondays.

Donburi devotees can dig into the Citrus Harvest Salmon Bowl, draped with delicately marinated sashimi, showered with ebiko, subtly uplifted with shiso leaves. Also enticing are the Zesty Yuzu Steak Bowl and the Apple Curry Chicken Curry Katsu Don.

For pasta, Inoha recommends the Creamy Lemon Duck Delight, drenched in a decadent ricotta-based dressing, with a robust depth of meaty flavour and crunchy texture from in-house dry-aged duck prosciutto, laced with lemon and spinach for a bit of brightness.

Inoha takes pride in distinctive desserts.

We love the Kuala Lipis Kek Batik, fudgy and fun, thickly layered with single-origin Malaysian cocoa, lined with Marie biscuits, piped with kaffir lime dark chocolate ganache, a diet-destroyer that's well worth the calories.

The Crispy Kataifi Banana Bliss raises fritters to crackly heights, bundled in phyllo pastry, snappy to the bite, ripely juicy to the chew, cushioned with true-blue blueberry jam, slathered with nut butter praline for an indulgence to thrill kids of all ages.

Inoha pours extra effort into its entire menu, spanning its own tepache and kombucha, plus coffee concoctions like Pudgy Express, expressive with espresso, milk and ice cream soda.

entry.title: 10 Ten Baker, PJ Old Town
entry.content:
PJ Old Town’s new 10 Ten Baker, helmed by a husband-and-wife team, is a welcomingly homely bakery-cafe where faith and fresh cakes come together. 

From Tuesday to Saturday, seek solace in soft hojicha burnt cheesecakes coupled with matcha lattes; on Sunday, search for serenity when this space hosts independent small church services.

entry.title: Obvi Pizza, Ara Damansara
entry.content: Peace, pizzas and piccolo lattes: Ara Damansara's new Obvi Pizza might not be obviously noticeable from the streets, but it's worth climbing the stairs for carbs, calm and caffeine - the Margherita is the classic, flavourful with tomato sauce, buffalo mozzarella and basil, while the coffee currently harnesses Ghostbird's Aurora blend.

entry.title: Nōto Cafe, Subang Jaya
entry.content:
Subang Jaya's new Nōto Cafe is a soothing space with soulful Japanese inspirations, warmed by a welcoming team, beautiful for a brunch of shokupan toast with hojicha burnt cheesecake and ceremonial-grade matcha lattes. 

Fun note: Nōto previously ran as a mobile coffee pop-up, mainly in campuses like Sunway University and Taylor's University. It now shares its new physical space with URA Autospa.

entry.title: 2t1n Kopi, Imbi
entry.content: A snapshot of serenity in Imbi: 2t1n Kopi is a new caffeine bar tucked inside the Saujana Film Lab processing studio, serving specialities like pecan oatmilk lattes for cosy caffeinated calm.

entry.title: Day Dream Cafe, Puchong
entry.content: Dream a little dream of playful drinks at Puchong’s new Day Dream Cafe, holding space for caffeination in creamy and fizzy forms, with the melt-in-the-mouth mascarpone of tiramisu and cinnamon scent of Thanksgiving apple pies.

entry.title: Hut Sake Bar thrills with Bluefin Tuna Cutting Ceremony & New Upgraded Premium Buffet Dishes
entry.content:
Hut Sake Bar continues to thrill in LaLaport Bukit Bintang City Centre, hosting its first Bluefin Tuna Cutting Ceremony recently and unveiling its new upgraded Premium Buffet Dishes.

Chef Otsuka Kenji, a skilled Japanese chef with years of experience at Michelin-starred restaurants abroad, came together with Hut Sake Bar’s chefs to conduct the tuna cutting ceremony on 16 November 2024.

The centrepiece was a Fresh Bluefin Tuna, majestically weighing more than 90 kilograms, flown in directly from Japan for the ceremony.


It was an action-packed afternoon as dozens of guests gathered for lunch to witness the event.

The Bluefin Tuna 'Snoring' Feast began with the traditional Spanish-style El Ronqueo ceremony to display the dexterity and discipline of the chefs.

Fun fact: 'Snoring' of the tuna comes from the muffled sound that the knife makes when it runs through the tuna's spine. 


The procedure includes processes like the head removal, slicing behind the gills to make a clean cut through the vertebrae. 

Prized cuts, such as the cheek, collar and eye, can subsequently be extracted.

The tail is also cut to enable better access to the meat along the tuna's spine and to position the fish for further cuts with a stable base.

The rest of the tuna is typically divided into two large halves: the dorsal (back) and the belly.




Primary cuts of tuna include akami (lean red meat from the sides), chutoro (medium-fatty belly) and otoro (the fattiest, richest part from the belly).

The tuna cutting ceremony guided guests in discerning other key parts such as kama (collar of the tuna, a flavourful section), sesuji (the back muscle, leaner and located near the dorsal fin), kamashita (under the collar, known for its smooth texture) and harakami (the upper belly, with a good balance of fat and lean meat).



Every part of the tuna is used, true to the Japanese cultural concept of 'mottainai,' which conveys a sense of regret over waste, rooted in respect and gratitude for everything we have.

The Bluefin Tuna Cutting Ceremony will be held monthly at a randomly selected partner restaurant. The remaining tuna meat will be sent to partner restaurants for sale, including Sushi Yoshi (LaLaport BBCC), Yakiniku Tenshin (Avenue K), Tengyu Omakase (Avenue K), Tsukiji Sushi (Avenue K), Tsukiji Sushi (Plaza Arkadia), Tsukiji Sushi (TTDI), and Tsukiji Sushi by Ten Omakase (Empire Shopping Gallery).


After the ceremony, guests savoured specially curated dishes to spotlight the bluefin tuna's exquisite taste and texture - a culinary masterpiece with full-bodied, buttery flesh, deep-red with a flavour that's darker and bolder than most tuna.

Hut Sake Bar has also newly launched its upgraded Premium Buffet menu starting at RM268. 

The Premium Buffet includes the Premium Platter, a sensational showcase for Salmon, Oyster, Tako, Maguro, Chutoro, Aka Ebi, Caviar, Torigai, Shiro Maguro, Uni and Hamachi.

You can also relish the Super Platter, a masterpiece of Snow Crab, Salmon, Tako, Chutoro, Aka Ebi, Caviar, Torigai, Shiro Maguro, Kohada, Hotate, Uni and Hamachi, representing the best bounty of the oceans.

For meat enthusiasts, the Premium Buffet includes Champion Third-Generation Shimomura Wagyu Beef served as Sushi, Nabemono, Sando and Donburi.

Also savoury unlimited tastings of abalone, chutoro, Japanese oysters, engawa, snow crab, foie gras, three types of shellfish (torigai, akagai and mirugai) and more!

Other buffet tiers include:

The Supreme Buffet Experience, starting from RM468, with additional sumptuous dishes such as the Uni Cone, the melt-in-your-mouth Shimomura A5 Wagyu with Foie Gras, Chutoro Uni Sushi, Uni Roll, and much more.

For the ultimate feast, the Luxurious Buffet starts from RM868, comprising all the premium offerings plus exquisite additions like King Crab, Lobster, fresh Uni and decadent Caviar.


Super Platter


Foie Gras Roll



Foie Gras Tamago


Foie Gras Don


Foie Gras Sando



Engawa with Uni Sushi
Shiro Maguro Uni Sushi

Also enjoy curated cocktails and mocktails to accompany the delightful dishes.






Hut Sake Bar
G97, Lalaport Bukit Bintang City Centre, Jalan Hang Tuah, 55100 Kuala Lumpur.
Daily, 11am-12am. 
WhatsApp: 011-3686-6881
www.hutsakebar.com
For bookings, click here

entry.title: Pastea Cafe, Paramount Garden
entry.content:
Paramount Garden’s new Pastea Cafe is a peaceful stop for pork rendang nasi lemak and hojicha lattes in a welcomingly bright, leafy neighbourhood space with Kacey Musgraves on the lunchtime playlist.

Pastea Cafe’s Malacca-origin founders plan to start serving Kristang and Nyonya classics by Christmas, spanning seybak to keluak.

entry.title: Ora Dining celebrates Christmas with Glazed Baby Back Beef Ribs, Koji Spring Chicken, Poached Pear Bread Pudding
entry.content:
Ora Dining is spreading Christmas culinary cheer with its festive creations, now available for dine-in and takeaway until 31 December 2024.

Make the season mouthwateringly merry with Glazed Baby Back Beef Ribs, Koji Spring Chicken with Perigourdine Sauce, and Poached Pear Bread Pudding, the perfect platters for feasting with family and friends.

Ora Dining's chef Xing Yu and the terrifically talented elves in his kitchen brigade sprinkle Yuletide magic on each recipe, brining the beef and chicken in their special koji marinade, poaching pears in port, patiently pickling onions and roasting cauliflowers for scrumptious side dishes.

Make your dine-in reservations early or WhatsApp Ora Dining at 017-228-8471 for takeaway orders at least three days in advance.



Glazed Baby Back Beef Ribs with Apple Salad (RM368 for full rack, RM198 for half rack) make for a hearty celebratory meal to fill your Christmas table.

Ora Dining brines these back ribs in shio koji seasoning and foil-bakes them for three hours, resulting in a bouncy chew with a robust beefy flavour, glazed in gula Melaka and fermented habanero for savoury-sweet, slightly spiced slickness.

We love the accompanying apple salad, a tribute to Xing Yu's past stint as a chef in Manhattan, resembling an American Waldorf salad with sliced red apples, celery, raisins and walnuts gently dressed in mayo for juicy-creamy crunch, plus the thick potato puree with beef jus.



Dry-Aged Chicken with Perigourdine Sauce (RM188 for whole) is a limited-time take on Ora's famous chicken, aged for five days for thorough tenderness and tastiness, more satisfyingly succulent than a typical Christmas turkey, complete with roasted cauliflower tossed with pickled onions, fried potatoes, egg yolk and ricotta cheese, rounded out with truffled pink oyster mushroom sauce, carrot puree and vanilla foam for addictive dipping. 

Half-chicken servings (RM98) are also available exclusively for dine-in.




Don't miss Ora's Poached Pear Bread Pudding (RM58), fabulously full-bodied with toasted brioche that's custard-soaked overnight, cinnamon-scented for the heartwarming fragrance of Christmas, layered with luscious port wine-poached pear, caramelised bananas, vanilla chantilly, honey crumble and a jammy spread of blueberries and strawberries. Feliz Navidad!



Ora Dining
29, Lorong Datuk Sulaiman 7, Taman Tun Dr Ismail, 60000 Kuala Lumpur.
Open Tuesday-Thursday, 4pm-12am; Friday-Sunday, 12pm-12am; closed Monday. 
Tel: 017-228-8471

entry.title: Boucake, The Exchange TRX
entry.content:
Bounce to Boucake, The Exchange TRX’s new Japanese-inspired cafe with a calming view.

Pillowy souffle pancake all-day breakfasts with sausages, smoked salmon, sauteed mushrooms, salad and a sunny-side-up are among Boucake’s soft-launch highlights, alongside carbonara udon with duck breast and onsen egg, wagyu hamburg with Japanese rice and other crowd-pleasers.

entry.title: Borenos Fried Chicken, Puchong
entry.content:
Sabah-born Borenos Fried Chicken has opened its first Klang Valley branch in IOI Boulevard Puchong, a satisfying stop for fans of homegrown fried chicken brands. 

The chicken hits the spot for flavour and freshness, crisp-skinned and juicy-fleshed, clean-tasting with a mildly peppery spice blend, well-paired with Borenos’ gravy and a Bornean ginger-honey hot beverage.

entry.title: Common Feed: Now an Italian-Spanish restaurant & deli in Damansara Uptown
entry.content:
Common Feed has returned, as a new Italian-Spanish restaurant and deli in Damansara Uptown, serving fresh-baked focaccia sandwiches, rustic pastas, robust Neapolitan pizzas and more, with everything from Italian charcuterie to Spanish canned seafood for sale.

This is a cheerful, casual choice for lunch and dinner, warmly welcoming patrons to a charmingly furnished wood-toned space with a wood-fired oven in its open kitchen.

Browse for bottles of olive oil, cans of tomatoes, and wide-ranging cold cuts and cheeses, then kick back for a hearty meal. In the afternoon, focaccia sandwiches offer fast, tasty convenience; in the evening, pizzas prove perfect for sharing, bolstered by Spanish-style tapas.

Focaccia sandwich sets are the highlight from 11am to 3pm, at reasonable prices of RM23-RM29, including a choice of iced tea or coffee.

Six sandwich options are available - we could order a different one every workday, each with its own satisfying combo of tastes and textures: The ham lover’s Jambon Beurre (RM25), Mortadella & Stracciatella (RM27), creamy-spicy ‘Nduja & Stracciatella (RM27), Parma & Stracciatella (RM29), Meatballs & Gruyere (RM23) and Lamb Porchetta & Feta (RM25).

Common Feed has perfected the proportions: The focaccia is baked in-house, balanced between fluffy and full-bodied with a fragrantly pillowy bite, layered with lots of meat and cheese for addictively punchiness.

During dinner, the kitchen’s attention turns to twelve-inch pizzas, built on two-day-fermented dough, culminating in a pleasurably puffy-airy crust with depth of flavour, leopard-spotted with heartwarming heat.

Common Feed’s pizzas rank among our favourite in PJ - for carnivorous carb cravings, check out the Spicy Kielbasa (RM42) and Mortadella (RM45), showcasing the savoury succulence of sausages and salumi.

Common Feed is also our best bet for Panuozzo Napoletana, the lip-smacking pizza sandwich, lusciously crafted here with Parma ham and stracciatella cheese.

Dry pasta is served for lunch and fresh pasta for dinner, with a lunch selection of umami-rich, briny-earthy Anchovy & Porcini Burro (RM25 including iced tea or drip coffee), Fusilli Pesto, Meatball Amatriciana and more.

Dinner pasta temptations include the citrus-brightened Al Limone with a choice of Spanish sardines or tuna for fish-fuelled fun (RM38), Carbonara, cooked with hand-rolled strozzapreti for a firm Italian 00-flour bounce in an eggy, guanciale-tossed tribute to classic Roman no-cream traditions (RM40), Truffle Serrano, Aceite de Gambas, and Crab Pesto.

Common Feed’s risotto deserves a shout-out of its own, convincingly al dente, decadent with smooth foie gras and silky porcini mushrooms, worthy of a top trattoria (RM62). Risotto with chorizo and clams is also available. 

For small plates to share, we love the Chicken Liver Mousse with melt-in-the-mouth, velvety richness, complete with lavish crackers (RM23), ‘Nduja Clams, featuring plump, juicy molluscs, mouthwatering in tangy-sweet sauce blended with ‘nduja salumi (RM42), Gambas al Ajillo, doing justice to the Spanish staple with market-fresh crustaceans, aromatically garlicky (RM38) and Galician Spanish Octopus, mixed up with sausage slices for an extra kick, comfortingly cushioned with potatoes (RM43). Cheese and charcuterie platters also sound super-tempting.


Common Feed’s tiramisu is impeccable - for dessert devotees, it’s worth visiting for this delicately whipped wonder even on its own. Fun fact: On Friday evenings for dinner, Common Feed serves up a playful special - scoop all the tiramisu you want from the kitchen’s tray to your plate for just RM25!


Common Feed 
115G, Jalan SS21/37, Damansara Utama, 47400 Petaling Jaya, Selangor. 
Open Tuesday-Sunday, 11am-3:30pm, 5:30pm-10pm. 
Tel: 03-7731-7313

entry.title: Lemak by VUVU, Bangsar South
entry.content:
Bangsar South's new family-owned Lemak by VUVU takes pride in a Terengganu mother's prize-winning recipe for ayam lemak, aromatic with lemongrass and local spices, served with steamed rice or mihun for a satisfying meal.

Fun fact: Vuvu is a cute moniker blurted out by one of the family's young children while they were brainstorming for names.

entry.title: Shouka, Bukit Jelutong
entry.content: Smash burgers for brunch: Beef and buns come out bright and early at Bukit Jelutong’s Shouka, with sizzlingly juicy burgers off the griddle beginning 10am.

entry.title: Air Day Coffee, Taman Seputeh
entry.content:
Air Day Coffee is a beautiful new sanctuary for the soul, offering a breather in Bukit Seputeh beside the Syed Putra highway.

Friendly co-founder Lex and his team have lovingly crafted a space of soothing solace, largely lined with wood fittings, some hand-built, exuding a humane warmth with wide windows looking out on laid-back leafiness.

Analogue inspirations abound, from a manual-lever espresso machine to music cassette deck players, amid flourishing English ivy, begonias and rubber plants representing essential elements of life.

With T-Bone Walker singing the blues on the speakers, mornings are calm and cosy here, with fresh-baked apple crumble pies and fragrant coffee beckoning.

When We Meet Is the ideal introduction, bringing together the bittersweet Ethiopian Nano Chala G1 Washed filter with an Ethiopian Gedeb Lalisa Village Natural cold brew blended with pineapple juice, milk and Earl Grey lavender syrup, plus scrumptiously soft hojicha sponge cake with white chocolate and passion fruit cream.

If you admire cafes with a genuine personal character, check this out. Air Day Coffee roasts its own beans, available for sale along with home brewing equipment.

GF17, Jln Syed Putra, Bukit Seputeh, 50460 Kuala Lumpur.

entry.title: Ora Dining turns one in TTDI with new dishes & desserts, from duck chorizo pasta to coconut parfait
entry.content:
Ora Dining turns one in Taman Tun Dr Ismail, celebrating its first birthday with new temptations on its modern European menu!

For the first time, Ora Dining has introduced duck dishes, relying on Ipoh-raised duck, dry-aged for five days in Ora's own kitchen, pleasurably seared for a protein powerhouse platter or tossed with farfalle and mussels for surf-and-turf pasta.

Ora's signature spring chicken recipe has been revamped too, now with a triumphant trifecta of Perigourdine sauce, carrot puree and vanilla foam for a surprising sojourn of flavours.

And finally, Chef Xing Yu and his team have unveiled new desserts that took months to perfect, breathing imaginative inspirations into the Mont Blanc Chocolate Cremeux with Oolong Ice Cream, Lychee Osmanthus Sorbet and Coconut Parfait with Mango Sauce.

Combined with cool cocktails and mocktails, Ora Dining is a confident choice for an enjoyable evening with family and friends, marching into its second year as one of the TTDI neighbourhood's most distinctive dining destinations.



Duck devotees, drop by for Ora's Dry-Aged Duck with Marsala Jus (RM110).

After five days of patient in-house dry-aging, the breast meat is lusciously smooth with a rich depth of penetrating flavour, impeccably juicy from its browned skin to pink flesh.

Accompaniments elevate Ora's creations further - the duck is paired not only with classically earthy marsala wine jus but salsa-like sauce vierge for tomato brightness and fig puree for nectarous sweetness, spiked with Mexican-style ancho and guajillo peppers for mild heat, rounded out with Cameron asparagus and eggplant with creme fraiche. The result: An exuberant pollination of international influences, coming together in harmonious balance.



Ora's Farfalle with Duck Chorizo and Mussels (RM85) is one of our current favourite pastas, a lip-smacking meet-up of meat and molluscs.

Silky bow-tie pasta surfaces with a bouncy pinch, punchily soaking in savoury, slow-cooked Calabrian leek sauce with a smoky char, sharpened with fresh tomatoes and gula Melaka for a gorgeous Malaysian embellishment, tossed with textured duck chorizo sourced from an honest butcher, firm New Zealand green mussels and flaky pecorino cheese.




Over the past year, one of Ora's most-ordered dishes has been chicken with mochi and beurre blanc - but the restaurant keeps reinventing and refining its recipes, launching a new rendition of its Koji Spring Chicken (half-chicken for RM88).

The chicken, fresh from the TTDI market, remains a crowd-pleaser, dry-aged for five days, marinated with shio koji fermented rice seasoning to accentuate the meat's natural taste and tenderness.

Vibrant new accompaniments transform this one-plate meal into a journey for the palate - cheerful carrot puree laced with sherry vinegar, contrasting with darkly aromatic truffled Perigourdine sauce, uplifted with lightly airy vanilla foam. Have them individually or together - miraculously, everything works.


If you adore original desserts, Ora Dining is worth a stop simply for sweet treats.

The Mont Blanc Chocolate Cremeux (RM42) is a scrumptious synergy of East and West - a base of Valrhona cremeux and chestnut puree is capped with soothing oolong tea ice cream, flanked with almond sables, beautifully bridging a Parisian patisserie and Taiwanese teahouse.


Cool vibes continue with the Lychee Osmanthus Sorbet (RM42), fragrantly floral and fruity, gently icy with Lillet Rosé granita, subtly enriched with caramelised white chocolate and cream cheese foam to evoke the layered inflections of milk tea. Delicate with elegant restraint.



For the young at heart of all generations, Coconut Parfait with Mango Sauce (RM36) furnishes a fine finish, infusing French foundations of technique with nostalgic Malaysian notes for melt-in-the-mouth spoonfuls of custardy coconut, succulently ripe mango, lychee cream and black sesame crumbs.



Ora Dining stays open till midnight, so feel free to linger after dinner or to pop by for late drinks, sipping on cocktails with tropical twists such as the Velvet Tropique (RM40; pandan-infused vodka with elderflower) and Dewdrop Martini (RM40; dry vermouth and vodka with honeydew and clarified mango juice).



Mocktails showcase a playful side that cafe-hoppers can relish, spanning the caffeinated kick of the Apple Pie (RM20; espresso, cinnamon, vanilla and apple) and Espress-O-range (RM20; espresso with orange sherbet).

Ora Dining
29, Lorong Datuk Sulaiman 7, Taman Tun Dr Ismail, 60000 Kuala Lumpur.
Open Tuesday-Thursday, 4pm-12am; Friday-Sunday, 12pm-12am. 
Tel: 017-228-8471

entry.title: Off Grid, Taman Paramount
entry.content:
Taman Paramount's new Off Grid is on point for nourishing meals of nutrient-dense, minimally processed whole foods with bold flavours. 

Build your own bowl, with a base like sweet potatoes, mixed salad leaves or multigrain rice, packed with proteins such as Japanese curry tofu, peri-inspired chicken thigh or grilled beef, supplemented by black beans with chilli, cherry tomatoes, corn salsa, broccoli, ajitsuke tamago and more, topped with pomegranate, sunflower seeds, pumpkin seeds or chopped almonds, finished with Bragg's apple dressing, sesame sauce and others.

Off Grid is currently single-handedly helmed by Eu Jun, likely as a six-month daytime pop-up in the latest location of The Rebel Penguin of Whimzy Town cocktail bar.

37A, Jalan 20/16, Taman Paramount, 46300 Petaling Jaya, Selangor.

entry.title: Le Trou Au Mur, Marrakesh
entry.content: Our favourite restaurant in Marrakesh, Le Trou Au Mur offers intriguing classic Moroccan recipes rarely seen elsewhere in the world - try the tride, a plate of shredded savoury pancakes crowned with chicken, egg and lentils in a saffron-and-herb sauce; the offal trifecta of lamb liver, kidney and heart; and mechoui, spit-roasted lamb leg, shoulder and saddle. Don't skip dessert (the ras el hanout ice cream is one-of-a-kind, gently flavoured with the country's most cherished spice mix) or drinks (Moroccan beer and wines are surprisingly satisfying). Bonus points for the friendliest service crew we encountered throughout Morocco, gliding efficiently across this comfortably elegant space in Marrakesh's medina.

entry.title: Papibu, Alfa Bangsar
entry.content:
Papi-who? Remember the name: Bangsar’s friendly new Papibu is likely to launch by December, pairing bakes and brews in the affably airy retail lobby of Alfa Bangsar on Maarof Road.

Papibu cultivates a cheerful community space; on a Saturday morning, it teamed up with Weekend Athletics to recharge runners after a six-kilometre dash through the neighbourhood with espresso tonics, matcha lattes and oat milk chocolate coolers, coupled with croissants and chocolate pastries, enjoyably worth the calories.

entry.title: Le Dauphin, Algeria
entry.content: Set by the sea, Le Dauphin's nets teem with the creatures of the deep, with freshly caught Mediterranean sardines and shrimp heaped on the grills for the hungry crowds in Algeria's coastal province of Tipaza.

entry.title: Siu House, 3 Damansara
entry.content: Siu House is 3 Damansara mall's sizzling new spot for smoky succulence - savour the claypot beef rice bowl laced with lots of luscious beef fat, cumin-spiced gelatinous pork knuckles, and grilled Cameron sweet corn for a cheat-day indulgence.

entry.title: Kiku, Yap Ah Shak House
entry.content:
Kiku is the city’s new Japanese-inspired intimate cafe and bar, a jazzy sanctuary with the Gerry Mulligan Quartet playing on the speakers for soothing mornings.

Officially open 9am to 6:30pm, Monday to Saturday, Kiku infuses a contemporary jazzu kissa’s sleek charm with timeless vinyl vibes, tucked on the third floor of Chow Kit’s Yap Ah Shak House.

Kiku’s selection spans shokupan toasts to sandos, donburi to ramen, all at reasonable prices. Munch on marvellously runny sunny-side-up pasture-raised eggs on fluffy buttered milk bread (RM12) and hamburg donburi of fresh-ground grilled beef patty with onsen egg and shoestring fries, soulfully hearty with koshihikari short-grain rice and miso soup (RM26).

Drinks range from Kyoto-origin hojicha lattes to potent potions like Takeshi’s Cooler, crisp with a rice cracker and nori cone atop sensuously mixed Gekkeikan sake with umeboshi syrup and yuzu bitters.

Service shimmers with warmth and attentive dedication, complementing the thoughtfully executed fare.

entry.title: Toastiful, Damansara Uptown
entry.content: Damansara Uptown's new Toastiful does beautiful cheese toasties - thick sourdough slices, cooked golden-brown to order, hot and meltingly tender with a freshly grated four-cheese blend of Parmesan, cheddar, mozzarella and gouda, layered with fillings like beef pastrami, pickles and mustard mayo.

entry.title: Pandan Cafe Dining, Taman Tun Dr Ismail
entry.content: True to its name, TTDI’s friendly new Pandan Cafe is passionate about pandan - spring for the subtly pandan-scented rice platter with lemongrass seafood curry, pleasantly paired with pandan onde-onde cake and pandan coolers laced with fresh coconut flesh.

entry.title: Inoha Cafe, Ara Damansara
entry.content:
Ara Damansara is set to say aloha to Inoha Cafe, opening 1 December 2024, serving imaginative Japanese-influenced specialities starting next month.

Asagohan sounds like a scrumptious breakfast, showcasing miso-marinated sea bass with tsuyu egg, tofu, natto, daikon, wakame and miso soup. Kombu-Kissed Shrimp features fusion flair with pasta tossed in kombu cream sauce with butter shrimp and ebiko.

Also intriguing: Inoha’s own Kuala Lipis Kek Batik, crafted with Malaysian cocoa and kaffir lime ganache.

Espresso-based beverages currently harness the Mawar Colombian-Javanese blend by KL’s Tatih Roastworks.

Inoha is spearheaded by some of the most genuinely welcoming founders, who met while working in cafes. This is their first own place together, well worth bookmarking for a visit - it’s a work in progress, with furnishing still coming in to complement the Pudgy Penguin on the counter; a table by the window is the perfect spot for sweater-weather serenity.

entry.title: G.F.P. Girlfriends' Place, Bangsar South
entry.content: New in Bangsar South, G.F.P. (Girlfriends' Place) is a warm initiative by wonderful hosts Holly, Stephanie and Carmen to welcome guests into a SoHo suite for cosy wine nights, Thursdays to Sundays. Reservations are required, with each small group chilling out in their own corner in this duplex, snacking on chips, cheese and siu yuk while sipping biodynamic wines by the bottle, feeling comfortably at home away from home.

entry.title: Single Dose Coffee, Petaling Jaya
entry.content:
Single Dose Coffee has a new home, moving from Bangsar to a neighbourhood enclave of PJ Old Town - a calm corner with cottage-like charm, by a team with a warm soul and welcoming spirit.

A thoughtful selection is served, from the house special of Brazil Ibiraci Peaberry for espresso-based beverages to Guatemala Finca La Cabana Geisha for filters, plus varietals spanning Burundi, Costa Rica, Ethiopia, Kenya, Peru and more.

Our lattes were lovely, with clean, nutty-chocolaty notes; our pour-over was perfect, with papaya-grape fruitiness and jasmine florality; coupled with the creamiest home-baked hojicha chocolate cake.

Fun fact: This is now the fresh location for Tyler Coffee Workshop too, with retail shelves for home brewing and personal care products. Bonus points for plant enthusiasts - Single Dose Coffee’s begonias and bird’s nest ferns are beautifully tended.

1, Lorong 1/10a, Seksyen 1, 46000 Petaling Jaya, Selangor.

entry.title: Teaxini, Petaling Jaya
entry.content:
PJ's new tea-and-coffee bar is a rustic place of relaxation, personally run by two founders with plenty of character and charm, restored with corners of hand-crafted clay cups and keepsakes.

Chinese tea, Japanese matcha and Malaysian-roasted coffee all find a sense of belonging here; choices include Chaozhou Ju Duo Zai oolong tea and ceremonial-grade matcha, brewed and whisked to order, soothing for sipping. Also try caffeine coolers like ginger-blended coffee.

Teaxini's founders have day jobs that keep them busy on weekdays, so their space is currently open 6pm-9pm Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, 2pm-9pm Saturdays, 11am-7pm Sundays.

92, Jalan SS 9a/1, Ss 9a, 47300 Petaling Jaya, Selangor.

entry.title: Cantina Pasta e Vino, Taman Desa
entry.content: Cantina Pasta e Vino is Taman Desa’s friendly new cavern for fresh hand-crafted pasta - choices span the Italian and the American Carbonara, both featuring tagliatelle, the first traditionally tossed here with egg yolk, guanciale, Grana Padano and Sarawak black pepper, the latter saucier with creme fraiche, smoked pancetta, peas and sautéed mushrooms. Other modern-minded options in this stylish neighbourhood space include tortelli stuffed with smoked salmon ricotta, cushioned with tomato salsa, crispy breadcrumbs and pomodoro sauce. Cured cuts and wine are available too.

entry.title: The Trio Caffe, Happy Garden
entry.content:
Three treats to try at The Trio Caffe, Happy Garden's new neighbourhood cafe that’s helmed with heart, humour and honesty:

Sourdough toast topped with hummus and chickpeas, rounded out with rocket, sautéed mushrooms and balsamic-based sauce.

Thick, crispy potato rosti with poached egg and sour cream, paired with plump Thuringian-style sausage and leaves in lemon dressing.

Gnocchi swimming in indulgent cream sauce with seared salmon, crunchy with mixed nuts.

entry.title: Cafe Luna, Bukit Jelutong
entry.content: Prime pasta pleasure: Bukit Jelutong’s new Cafe Luna is currently serving a crave-worthy crustacean creation - prawn linguine with buttery prawn head oil, brimming with briny beauty in every bite.

entry.title: Garisan, Batu Caves
entry.content: Walk the line to Garisan, recently relocated to its own commercial space, a welcoming spot for oat milk hot chocolate and strawberry yoghurt coolers, plus coffee that relies on local roasters.

entry.title: UMI Japanese Restaurant, Imperial Lexis Kuala Lumpur
entry.content:
Decadent delicacies from the sea, soaring to fresh heights in KL's new destination for sushi, sashimi and more: With a 52nd-floor cityscape view from Imperial Lexis Kuala Lumpur, UMI Japanese Restaurant is a dazzling delight for fans of distinctive dining experiences.

Watch the sun set over the Petronas Twin Towers and KL Tower while savouring the sweetest fish, crustaceans and molluscs in sumptuous styles, spanning the Shiromi Sakana Carpaccio to Kaisen Hokkai Nabe to Karatsuki Hotate Kai Aburi Yaki.

UMI's ceiling-height glass walls promise an unparalleled panorama of KL as golden hour gives way to glittering cosmopolitan night lights, visible from throughout the spacious dining hall to the sleek private room.

UMI - which means 'sea' in Japanese - offers a comprehensive a la carte menu that expertly embraces the touchstones of Japanese gastronomy, from tempura to teppanyaki.

Basking in a naturally soft glow before twilight, UMI serves dinner from Tuesdays to Sundays; it's a vibrant venue in the city centre for a romantic rendezvous and memorable celebrations.




For intimate milestones, a private room comfortably accommodates about 18 to 30 guests with ease, with a minimum spend of RM5,000.




Catch a glimpse of the kitchen brigade calmly at work, led by head chef Danny, whose 28 years of professional experience in Japanese cuisine includes stints in Fukuoka, Japan, as well as in Britain and China.



For a spectacular starter, sample the Shiromi Sakana Carpaccio (RM118), a medley of the chef's selected sashimi that represents the pinnacle of the season, brightened with the lively tang of a yuzu citrus dressing, aromatically balanced with earthy garlic oil, buoyed by briny caviar for a zesty synergy of both sea and land.


Smooth, thick slices of raw seafood, pure and pristine, take centre stage in the Kyuten Mori Sashimi (RM458), showcasing nine varieties of the ocean's opulence. Presently, patrons might relish possibilities from delicately subtle karei (flounder) to lusciously marbled otoro (tuna belly), rounded out with botan ebi, tako, salmon belly, hamachi, ikura, hotate and uni for an exuberant exploration of the finest international catch.


The  Lobster Roll (RM238) emerges strikingly, a majestic maki plumply stuffed with deep-fried lobster meat, fleshy, firm and full-bodied, exquisitely elevated above conventional shrimp sushi rolls.



The Spider Roll (RM78) surfaces in a web of intrigue, tantalising our taste buds with the crackly crunch of soft-shell crab, blanketed in bonito flakes and roe for a mouthwatering maki, bursting with taste and texture.


UMI's specialities comprise the classic and the contemporary. 

For a colourfully fun fusion of Japanese, Korean and Latin American flavours, try the Tako Kimchi with Mango and Tomato Salsa (RM42), perking up the palate with juicy baby octopus marinated with gently spicy kimchi, tossed with edible flowers and herbs, evoking an underwater garden, harmoniously blending the bouncy bite of baby octopus with a nectarous harvest of tropical fruits and vegetables.



On rainy evenings, seek shelter from the storm with UMI's soulful, steamy Kaisen Hokkai Nabe (RM158), a spicy miso hotpot brimming with the deep umami of assorted seafood, such as prime zuwaigani snow crab, clams, mussels and salmon, restoring the spirit and nourishing the body with time-honoured cooking traditions.



Fire and flair: For tempting theatrics at the table, the Karatsuki Hotate Kai Aburi Yaki (RM88) is set aflame when served to reveal gorgeously grilled Hokkaido scallops, garnished with caviar, ikura and edamame, with a soothing smokiness to enhance the scallops' succulence.



Finish with the Chef's Special Fruit Platter (RM168, served with a rich house-churned coconut ice cream). It's a thoughtful ensemble of fruits cultivated from across Asia, carved out in captivating fashion for a remarkable runway of melon, mango, grapes, guava, apple and pear, possibly KL's most visually inspiring fruit platter!


UMI Japanese Restaurant
52nd Floor, Imperial Lexis Kuala Lumpur, 
15, Jalan Kia Peng, 50450 Kuala Lumpur.
Open Tuesdays-Sundays, 6pm-11pm. 
Closed Mondays.

For bookings & enquiries:
+603-2177-1188 / +6010-784-0176
eat@imperiallexiskl.com (Email)
Booking table link: letsumai.com/widget/umi-imperial-lexis

Find out more:
imperiallexiskl.com/dining/umi-japanese-restaurant
instagram.com/imperiallexiskl
facebook.com/imperiallexiskl
#MYLexis #ImperialLexisKL

entry.title: Malayan Chicken Rice, Sungai Way
entry.content: The flagship fare at Sungai Way’s new Malayan Chicken Rice might be its namesake nasi ayam, with commendably crisp-skinned meat - but its top temptation is the Muar otak omelette, a can’t-fail combo of soft eggs with spicy fish cakes, served fresh and steaming-hot.

entry.title: Sarawak Mini Smoke House, Puchong
entry.content: This Puchong kopitiam stall is rooted in rustic Borneo traditions, serving Sarawak's indigenous Dayak specialities such as manuk pansuh bamboo-cooked chicken, sup daun sabung and nasi goreng daun empasak, soup and rice with leafy herbaceous flavours.

entry.title: Cohii Culture, The ERA @ Duta North
entry.content:
Cohii Culture is the cool new corner for caffeine in The ERA @ Duta North, pairing playful beverages like the Marshmallow Caramel Macchiato, Earl Grey Cloud, Tiramisu Cocoa Latte, Matcha Lychee and Chocolate Dinosaur with pastries like the Otak-Otak Onicroissant.

Fun fact: This is Cohii Culture's first outpost but nearly certainly not its last - its next stop is slated for Taman Mayang in Petaling Jaya.

entry.title: Kantan, Wisma Cosway
entry.content: Chicken rice and soup noodles for the soul: Kantan is the city centre's new stop for fuss-free plates of fragrant rice with smooth steamed chicken and steaming-hot bowls of kai si hor fun with honest, heartwarming flavours in Wisma Cosway.

entry.title: Dhuri Cafe, Sungai Besi
entry.content: Sungai Besi's Dhuri Cafe is nuts about pastries - top treats include crackly, crunchy ribbon croissants and crombolinis, stuffed or studded with chocolate and hazelnuts.

entry.title: Jyuu Yen Omurice, Taman Cheras
entry.content:
Soft-launching this week, Jyuu Yen Omurice marks a new milestone, maturing from a streetside Sri Petaling stall into a full-fledged Cheras eatery - the speciality is the take on omurice with a silky-soft tornado omelette, customisable with toppings like deep-fried Australian beef patty or Taiwanese-style crispy chicken cutlet, complemented by sauces like a light-bodied apple puree Japanese curry (RM16-RM22 per hearty set, served with seaweed salad and sweet corn), rounded out with sides like Chinese sticky rice pumpkin cakes with mentaiko mayo for nan gua bing cheat-day capers. 

19, Block P/E, Jalan Cengkeh, Taman Cheras.

entry.title: Lao Bu Jia, Southgate
entry.content: Soul food in Southgate: The Lu Rou Mian at Lao Bu Jia is a comforting cross between lu rou fan and pan mee, a bowl to help heal the broken spirit.

entry.title: Moka Cafe, Pavilion Damansara Heights
entry.content: Cosy for calm, cool mornings, Pavilion Damansara Heights’ new Moka Cafe offers breezy alfresco relaxation for red bean mochi suisse and Victoria sponge cake with matcha lemonade.

entry.title: Torito, Banyan Tree Kuala Lumpur
entry.content:
Ceviche and causa, anticucho and acevichado: Torito is a tantalising new restaurant that promises Peruvian pleasures by Lima-born chef Ivan Casusol Rossi, who harnesses 22 years of professional experience in Latin American cooking.

Start with the star recipe, representing Peru's Pacific seafood heritage: Ceviche Clasico is Torito's tribute to citrus-marinated fish, moist but not mushy, firm with full-bodied fleshiness, its clean, natural purity of flavour enlivened with the traditional tiger's milk marinade of lime, chillies and cilantro, encircled with crackly-fried squid rings and orange sweet potatoes.

Causa embodies two cornerstones of Peruvian cuisine - potatoes and seafood: Torito layers comfortingly smooth mashed potatoes with thick-sliced hamachi and salmon sashimi, a nod to Peruvian-Japanese Nikkei inspirations for an irresistibly unique South American indulgence.

Cazuelas - shallow earthenware brimming with meat and the land's harvest - showcase soulful heartiness: A duet of duck, boneless leg confit and prosciutto-like cured breast, on soccarat-rich rice with red onion pickles, and a one-pot wonder of wok-fried beef tenderloin, tenderly channelling Peru's Chinese Chifa legacy, cushioned with creamy beans and coriander sauce.

Dessert possibilities include picarones - the Peruvian street-food staple of deep-fried sweet potato doughnuts is crispy-hot, with an earthy autumnal sweetness that reflects Torito's fermentation of the tuber, cooled with chef Ivan's own honeydew ice cream, secretly and subversively laced with blue cheese for delicately delectable depth.

With a 53rd-floor view from Banyan Tree Kuala Lumpur, tables at Torito deliver a dramatic tableau of KL's cityscape. Sparkling service supplements the shimmering skyline.

entry.title: SSavoury Restaurant, Petaling Jaya
entry.content:
Puppies and pappardelle: PJ’s new SSavoury Restaurant warmly welcomes pets and people to a bright space where wiener dogs wander while their humans savour SSavoury’s treats, from crab cakes to chargrilled chicken to chocolate brownies.

For pasta pleasure, have hearty helpings of lamb pappardelle with pine nuts and prawn aglio olio linguine with bird’s eye chillies, coupled with fruity tea coolers.

2, Jalan Kilang 51/206, Seksyen 51, 46050 Petaling Jaya, Selangor.

entry.title: Tengyu Omakase, Avenue K: Range of set menus include brand-new options starting from RM268
entry.content:
Here, guests can savour Shimomuragyu, a championship-winning beef at Japan's Wagyu Olympics, victorious for 10 straight years at Aichi Prefecture's esteemed wagyu tournament.

This halal-certified wagyu spotlights meticulous breeding for marvellously marbled meat with a superb fat-to-lean ratio, with an amino acid nutrition content that's 30 times higher than most A5 wagyu beef. Tengyu Omakase's careful charcoal cooking preserves the Shimomuragyu's rich juices, resulting in full-bodied flavour and fabulous textures.

The restaurant offers a wide variety of set menu options, including three new additions priced at RM268, RM888 and RM1,000 - the RM268 Ume Omakase, the RM888 Tengyu Special Omakase with unlimited orders of premium wagyu sirloin, rib-eye and uchimomo cuts for two hours, and the RM1,000 Sushi Yoshi × Tengyu Kiwami Omakase for both A5 shimomuragyu wagyu and sushi.

Tengyu Omakase is a terrific choice for Japanese food enthusiasts in KL's city centre, promising warm service in a comfortable space that comprises an open kitchen for grilling, as well as a private room for family gatherings and business dinners.




The Ume Omakase (RM268) is a budget-friendly meal that embraces all the essentials, starting with a trio of appetisers such as Shimomuragyu yukke, followed by today's chawanmushi and a seasonal salad.


The first main course displays three kinds of Shimomuragyu slices, with the chef selecting a journey of joyful cuts to accentuate the allure of this wagyu beef, such as the sirloin, short rib, short plate, chuck roll or chateaubriand.


The second main course is a playful hand-roll of wagyu sushi studded with ikura for bursts of briny and beefy flavours in every memorable mouthful.



The third main course is a yakiniku-grilled sirloin roll, stuffed with sushi rice and a plump egg yolk to be enjoyed together in triumphant harmony.



This omakase finishes with soulful, steaming-hot beef bone soup, concentrated with the nourishing benefits of beef, and a delightful plated dessert of the day.




The Tengyu Special Omakase (RM888) is available daily for lunch and dinner - the choice for patrons who crave as much beef as they can eat, with unlimited rounds of Shimomuragyu in a two-hour session.

The Tengyu Special Omakase begins with an appetiser of kale salad with special sauce, mushi mono of zuwai kani snow crab chawanmushi with ikura, sashimi of wagyu yukke with uni and caviar, and a premium course of teppanyaki Australian lobster.



The star attraction is the Premium Wagyu Parts - unlimited cuts of sirloin, ribeye and uchimomo (top round), replenished as often as you want, each with its own signature flavour profile, confidently cooked by Tengyu Omakase's chefs on the yakiniku grill.

This omakase ends with Owan Mono (Tengyu special soup) and Kudamono (seasonal fruits).



Tengyu Omakase has also launched a unique new omakase experience, bringing together two Japanese chefs to serve Shimomuragyu A5 wagyu yakiniku combined creatively with sushi.


This Ultimate Dual Delicacies celebration of culinary artistry is available exclusively by advance booking, only on the second Friday of every month in Tengyu Omakase at Avenue K.

Seize the opportunity to watch the work of Tengyu Omakase's Chef Takeda, who boasts over a decade of yakiniku experience in Tokyo, alongside Chef Otsuka from Sushi Yoshi, formerly showcasing their skills at the Michelin-starred Koy Shunka in Barcelona.


The Sushi Yoshi x Tengyu Kiwami Omakase kicks off with three types of daily appetisers; potential highlights from the sea include ankimo (luscious monkfish liver), tsubugai (umami-loaded whelk) and marinated samna (Pacific saury). 


The Gohan Mono soup course is a decadent duet of beef and oyster, featuring a plump Hokkaido oyster wrapped in silky-smooth Shimomuragyu sirloin.

Today’s Sashimi spotlights both seafood and Shimomuragyu in their pure raw forms, powerfully pristine to convey their clean, natural flavours. 



The first main course series for Yakiniku comprises two thick cuts of steak - the Teppan-Grilled Sirloin and the Chateaubriand Special, deliciously done to perfection, displaying different preparations (one on the teppan, the other over charcoal, served with the simplicity of truffled salt) for captivating contrasts of char and chew by Chef Takeda.



The second main course series is dedicated to Sushi, with a parade of nigiri sushi curated by Chef Otsuka to embody the excellence of the season's seas, such as mirugai (Pacific geoduck), otoro, akagai, madai,  kinmedai, ebodai and scallop with sea urchin.

There's also a surprise of Shimomuragyu chuck-rib beef gunkan sushi, delectably delicate, for a comparison of meat to follow the fish.




The Sushi Yoshi Ten-Gyu Special is a show-stopper - a spectacular bowl blanketed with the best of seafood and Shimomuragyu, from buttery zuwai kani snow crab to caviar and ikura.


Today’s Dessert concludes the courses with opulent French-inspired flair, reinterpreted with Japanese flavours, such as raspberry mousse cake baked by Tengyu Omakase's team.

Tengyu Omakase
